image.altText: Protest rally

items.synopsis: Upper house MPs spent all night debating the laws, which will significantly increase potential penalties for people who engage in disruptive protests.

title.children: Protest law changes pass SA parliament after marathon all-night debate

image.altText: A drone shot of a suburban housing estate.

items.synopsis: National house prices lifted sharply in May, according to data from CoreLogic. Sydney continues to lead the recovery, with rises across the capital cities, as the number of properties advertised for sale fell further.

title.children: Property price rebound gathering pace despite interest rate rises

image.altText: A worker lifts the top off a large grey and black battery.

items.synopsis: As Australia passes the milestone of 100,000 electric vehicles on our roads, an environmental downside is looming: huge numbers of batteries that could end up in landfill.

title.children: Electric vehicles are touted as key to a green future. But their batteries pose a triple-threat

image.altText: Left to right: June Oscar, Ian Hamm, Fred Hooper, Miriam-Rose Ungunmerr Baumann

items.synopsis: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Elders share stories and language, culture and wisdom, that have been passed down from generation to generation.

title.children: How Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Elders have shaped culture and country for tens of thousands of years

image.altText: Cameron Murray and Nathan Cleary look sad

items.synopsis: Desperate defence, a contentious sin-binning and a prop taking to the air all contributed to one of the most dramatic and unlikely State of Origin wins in Queensland history. Here's the five main talking points.

title.children: Miracle try savers, controversial bunker calls and a flying prop: Five things we learned from Origin I

image.altText: Two men celebrate after winning a State of Origin match

items.synopsis: After Queensland found all the answers in State of Origin I, New South Wales leaves Adelaide with nothing but more questions.

title.children: Why Queensland's triumph in Adelaide is yet another spin on the classic Maroons story

image.altText: a man looking

items.synopsis: The Victoria Cross recipient sued the Sydney Morning Herald, The Age, The Canberra Times and three journalists in the Federal Court over a series of articles published in 2018. Today Justice Anthony Besanko will deliver his judgement.

title.children: Judgment in Ben Roberts-Smith's extraordinary defamation battle set to be delivered

image.altText: A man in a suit looks at a wired technological contraption.

items.synopsis: The federal government proposes a possible classification system for AI technologies, with more stringent requirements for higher risk tools.

title.children: Government takes first steps to regulate AI, including possible risk classification system

image.altText: Philip Lowe wearing glasses and a suit sits at a table and speaks.

items.synopsis: Perhaps it was no accident that Philip Lowe used his Senate Estimates appearance to give the political class some advice about the need to rethink how Australia fights inflation, even if he knew his words would likely fall on deaf ears, writes David Speers.

title.children: At his last stand, Lowe gave some tough advice to the 'political class'. Then the inflation figures dropped

image.altText: Jason De Ieso was murdered in late 2012

items.synopsis: A Supreme Court murder trial into the alleged shooting of Jason De Ieso hears a key witness initially lied to police about a firearm believed to be linked to the 2012 death.

title.children: Jason De Ieso murder trial hears witness initially lied to police about gun linked to alleged shooting

image.altText: A close-up photo of a young man wearing a collared shirt and tie.

items.synopsis: A man who was shot dead by police in Adelaide's west four years ago made several calls to mental health services before his death.

title.children: Man made several calls to mental health lines before being shot dead by police

image.altText: An aerial view of rows of seated graduation students with colourful sashes over their black academic robes.

items.synopsis: All HECS-HELP loans will increase by 7.1 per cent today.

title.children: HECS-HELP loans are indexed today. Check how much your loan will increase with our calculator

image.altText: A farmer crouches on dry, cracked soil

items.synopsis: We are "destabilising the entire planet" warn an international team of scientists, who outline the planetary boundaries we need to stay within in order to provide a "safe and just" future.

title.children: 'At risk of destabilising the entire planet': Report lays down boundaries for 'safe and just' future

image.altText: Old portrait of of Sigmund Freud in his mid-thirties.

items.synopsis: These 19th century doctors and scientists experimented with drugs such as hashish, cocaine and chloroform. For some, it led to trouble. For others, it resulted in remarkable discoveries.

title.children: Freud once endorsed cocaine, but he was blindsided when people 'went crazy' about it

image.altText: railway packages for containers with uranium hexafluoride salt, raw material for nuclear reactors

items.synopsis: The International Atomic Energy Agency installs only a fraction of equipment it hoped for and estimates Iran has enough uranium enriched to up to 60 per cent for two bombs.

title.children: Monitoring equipment returns to only some Iranian sites as enriched uranium stock grows, IAEA reports

image.altText: Workers on scaffolding repaint the NASA logo near the top of the Vehicle Assembly Building at the Kennedy Space Center

items.synopsis: NASA holds its first public meeting on "unidentified aerial phenomena," commonly known as UFOs, a year after launching a study into unexplained sightings.

title.children: NASA holds first public talks on UFOs ahead of final report

image.altText: A man in a akubra style hat smiles at the camera while patting his white husky dog

items.synopsis: A police investigation has found the two officers involved in a fatal shooting in South Australia's Mid North earlier this month were acting in self-defence.

title.children: Crystal Brook shooting of Sean Ferris was in self-defence, investigation finds

image.altText: Crime scene tape outside a home.

items.synopsis: Police say the man was armed with a knife and threw roof tiles at officers, who were not injured, during a three-hour stand-off in Blair Athol.

title.children: Man who allegedly threw roof tiles at police arrested after stand-off in Adelaide's north

image.altText: SAS soldier overlooks valley in Afghanistan as Black Hawk helicopter flies past in 2012.

items.synopsis: Defence chief Angus Campbell reveals the United States military warned that allegations of war crimes may affect future cooperation with Australia.

title.children: War crime allegations prompted warnings from US about cooperation with Australia

image.altText: police cars with lights on

items.synopsis: A three-year-old boy is fatally stabbed, and a 45-year-old man has been taken to hospital in a critical condition, after an incident in Riverwood unit, which police are investigating.

title.children: Police investigate domestic violence after 3yo boy found fatally stabbed in Sydney home

image.altText: Philip Lowe wearing glasses and a suit sits at a table and speaks.

items.synopsis: The RBA governor says strong population growth is exacerbating Australia's housing crisis and we need more people to live in each dwelling.

title.children: Higher rents will help reduce rental stress by encouraging people to 'economise' on housing, RBA governor says

image.altText: Black letters that spell out PwC on a white wall with red, orange and yellow graphic squares above the letter C.

items.synopsis: PriceWaterHouse Coopers insists it will comply with a request to hand over information to the Tax Practitioners Board looking into the leaking of confidential treasury documents.

title.children: PwC asked to hand over more information amid new investigation into leak

image.altText: Jim Chalmers sitting in the House of Representatives. He holds his hand over his mouth.

items.synopsis: Treasurer Jim Chalmers says the naming of partners at consulting giant PwC involved in misusing confidential government information will happen "in time".

title.children: 'Ropeable' treasurer Chalmers says naming of PwC partners will happen 'in time'

image.altText: A smoker lights up a cigarette

items.synopsis: Health warnings on individual cigarettes and new graphic images on cigarette packets are among changes the federal government plans to introduce.

title.children: Tobacco industry to face tougher restrictions by 2025 under planned laws

image.altText: The Toyota logo on a red car.

items.synopsis: Toyota says the vehicle data and personal information of some Australian customers may have been publicly accessible due to a human error that saw a cloud storage system set to public instead of private.

title.children: Toyota Australia says some customers' information may have been publicly accessible

image.altText: A young woman wearing jeans and a white T-shirt leading a horse wearing a rug.

items.synopsis: Teenager Poppy Crozier's death on the Dukes Highway prompts calls from young people in Keith and her Adelaide school for the road to be upgraded, as the RAA seeks funding in the state budget.

title.children: Calls for SA highway to be duplicated after crash that killed young woman

image.altText: A picture of a woman in scrubs, cant see her face except that she's wearing a face mask and putting gloves on hands

items.synopsis: The Australian College of Nursing head says she is hearing from nurses across the country who say they are concerned about their safety while trying to deliver healthcare, reigniting calls for permanent onsite security at four regional hospitals in SA.

title.children: Riverland nurses call police during incident at hospital as calls grow for 24/7 onsite security

image.altText: A young Asian woman with long dark hair poses for a selfie.

items.synopsis: A Supreme Court jury finds a man guilty of murder, after he killed his girlfriend of only a few weeks and dumped her body in a household rubbish bin.

title.children: Man who searched 'How many years for killing a person in Australia?' convicted of girlfriend's murder

image.altText: People laying around and playing volleyball on a tropical beach

items.synopsis: Authorities in Bali will distribute a list of "dos and do nots" for visitors arriving at the tourist island and are warning they will cancel visas amid a wave of disrespectful tourists.

title.children: Bali tourists to receive 'dos and don'ts' card on arrival as part of crackdown on unruly behaviour

image.altText: a man wearing dark glasses leaving court

items.synopsis: A former student at the high school where convicted killer Chris Dawson taught tells a court of the moment she saw her schoolmate sitting on his lap.

title.children: Former student tells Sydney court she saw her friend 'sitting on' Chris Dawson's lap in school

image.altText: NIBLITT OUTSIDE HOUSE

items.synopsis: Two years after signing a $430,000 fixed price contract, boilermaker David Niblitt can no longer afford to finish the home that he and his wife had hoped they'd be living in by now.

title.children: David's half-built house is an 'absolute nightmare' and might send him bankrupt

image.altText: Above view of inside parliament, a large group sit on the right a much smaller group on the left.

items.synopsis: The bill still needs to be dealt with by the Senate, which is likely next month, before the federal government sets a date for the poll later this year.

title.children: Indigenous Voice to Parliament referendum bill passes lower house; Nationals, some Liberals voting against

image.altText: A tennis player smiles at the camera

items.synopsis: The world’s top-ranked male tennis player Carlos Alcaraz is inspiring fans and competitors with his talent and winning smile. Could the young Spaniard become the new king of Roland Garros?

title.children: Why a French Open triumph could make Carlos Alcaraz the new king of Roland Garros

image.altText: A woman standing in front of a shipping container

items.synopsis: Sally Marvin lost her home to floods and has been housed in temporary accommodation since January — she still does not know when it will be safe to return home.

title.children: After six months in huts, these WA flood victims are still waiting to go home
